sn16.3:4.2: “Mendicants, you should approach families like the moon:
sn16.3:4.3: withdrawn in body and mind, always the newcomer, and never impudent.
sn16.3:4.4: Suppose a person were to look down into an old well, a rugged cliff, or a treacherous river.
sn16.3:4.5: They’d withdraw their body and mind.
sn16.3:4.6: In the same way, you should approach families like the moon.
sn16.3:4.7: withdrawn in body and mind, always the newcomer, and never impudent.
sn16.3:5.1: Kassapa approaches families like the moon:
sn16.3:5.2: withdrawn in body and mind, always the newcomer, and never impudent.
sn16.3:5.3: What do you think, mendicants? What kind of mendicant is worthy of approaching families?”
sn16.3:5.4: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and refuge.
sn16.3:5.5: Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this.
sn16.3:5.6: The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
sn16.3:6.1: Then the Buddha waved his hand in space.
sn16.3:6.2: “Mendicants, this hand is not stuck or held or caught in space.
sn16.3:6.3: In the same way, when approaching families, a mendicant’s mind is not stuck or held or caught, thinking:
sn16.3:6.4: ‘May those who want material possessions get them, and may those who want merit make merits!’
sn16.3:6.5: They’re just as pleased and happy when others get something as they are when they get something.
sn16.3:6.6: This kind of mendicant is worthy of approaching families.
sn16.3:7.1: When Kassapa approaches families, his mind is not stuck or held or caught, thinking:
sn16.3:7.2: ‘May those who want material possessions get them, and may those who want merit make merits!’
sn16.3:7.3: He’s just as pleased and happy when others get something as he is when he gets something.
sn16.3:8.1: What do you think, mendicants? What kind of mendicant’s teaching is pure, and what kind is impure?”
sn16.3:8.2: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and refuge.
sn16.3:8.3: Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this.
sn16.3:8.4: The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
sn16.3:8.5: “Well then, mendicants, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
sn16.3:9.1: “Whoever teaches Dhamma to others with the thought:
sn16.3:9.2: ‘Oh! May they listen to the teaching from me. When they’ve heard it, may they gain confidence in the teaching and demonstrate their confidence to me.’
sn16.3:9.3: Such a mendicant’s teaching is impure.
sn16.3:10.1: Whoever teaches Dhamma to others with the thought:
sn16.3:10.2: ‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—realizable in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.
sn16.3:10.3: Oh! May they listen to the teaching from me. When they’ve heard it, may they understand the teaching and practice accordingly.’
sn16.3:10.4: So they teach others because of the natural excellence of the teaching, out of compassion, kindness, and sympathy.
sn16.3:10.5: Such a mendicant’s teaching is pure.
sn16.3:11.1: Kassapa teaches Dhamma to others with the thought:
sn16.3:11.2: ‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—realizable in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.
sn16.3:11.3: Oh! May they listen to the teaching from me. When they’ve heard it, may they understand the teaching and practice accordingly.’
sn16.3:11.4: So he teaches others because of the natural excellence of the teaching, out of compassion, kindness, and sympathy.
sn16.3:11.5: I will exhort you with the example of Kassapa or someone like him. You should practice accordingly.”
